commentBody: ULTA/INUK and SAL/ELON, two potential Naticks on a Tuesday. The U obviously had to be a vowel, and I suppose Elon fails under "crosswordese"
Couple of potential naticks for a Tuesday (SAL/ZARA and INUK/ULTA), hope people don't get too caught up here.

Great puzzle fortunately I had a sweet snack to go with it. A little early in the week for the aforementioned natiks.
Will we see Grahame Greene who passed today honoured soon?
This puzzle did not tie me up in knots, nor was it terribly crunchy, so there was no need for me to feel salty while solving.  I did like MOMAGER and the clue for INTEL.

I seem to remember Rena Cohen's grids tend to rely too much on proper names and trivia, and today's was no different. I solved it without outside help in regular Tuesday time but I can't say I enjoyed it, really. The theme did nothing for me, either. Pretzel shapes. Well, ok. /shrug

Poland's iconic shape for a pretzel-like snack is sticks. We call them paluszki, little fingers, and they were one of the few salty snacks made over here before 1989. They are still quite popular.
Proud to say I've consumed the very pretzels this puzzle inspired... WashU represent!!!

"I love the new salt you're using on your doughy snacks!"
"What a twist, huh? It's my pretzel sharpener!"

(I love pretzels! How could you knot?)
Pass the mustard, please.
Good clues!

‚ÄúThese pretzels are making me thirsty!‚Äù 
 (From Seinfeld üòÅ)
"These pretzels are making *me* thirsty!" "These pretzels are *making* me thirsty!" "THESE PRETZELS....making me THIRSTY!" https://www.youtube.com/shorts/B8Kh0HmfJTY
Yes.
Two Naticks in one Tuesday puzzle is rarity. SAL/ZARA and INUK/ULTA. All four words were completely new to me.
Annual rant time - NYTXW can‚Äôt go a week without mentioning a certain South American country my ex is from - double time today - Lima Peru and Senora today - couldn‚Äôt fit in alpaca or Inca?
Easy breezy beautiful
When the answer is SENORAS (actually SE√ëORAS), entering MUJERES tends to slow one down a bit.

New product launches:

For the fan of really really stale snacks: 
TITANIUM pretzels
For the very young:
TEETHING pretzels 
For the vodka drinking snacker:
RUSSIAN pretzels 
For the narcissist:
SELFIE pretzels

Fairly smooth Tuesday, although I had to find a typo. Didn't have much trouble except I wasn't all that familiar with SAL Khan, although I've hear of the Academy as a good online resource. Not familiar with ZARA, but I was familiar with ELON since this is the fifth time it's appeared this year, and 95th in the Shortz era. ULTA was familiar because it's present in a lot of the shopping centers that I've visited over the last 10 years or so.

My other minor quandary was WORKs at instead of WORK FOR, but that didn't match up with the crosses, so got fixed quickly.

Nice puzzle. Rena, and thanks!

Our esteemed columnist can't distinguish logs from sticks. Like their wooden counterparts, pretzel sticks are shorter and thinner while logs are longer and thicker. Logs are much better at providing a perch for a glob of viscous dip like hummus. Faced with the same challenge, a stick will break and leave a hapless shard irretrievably moored in the dip bowl and you holding a dry dipless crumbling remnant.
A bit too easy but also too many brand and proper names. Lots of repeating clues and words,  although I give the puzzler points for coming up with a different clue for ANI.
Re 57d:  Nemo doesn‚Äôt really interact with Dory.  It‚Äôs his dad, Marlin, who‚Äôs the pal

I also fell victim to the SAt/EtON crossing. But SAt was the only thing that looked odd to me, so it was an easy enough fix. Fun to see ELIS, ELIE, ELON and ILE in the same puzzle. 

Thanks, Rena. 

Happy Tuesday everyone ‚ò∫Ô∏è

If Pretzelholic Anonymous existed I would be a charter member. I inherited my obsession from my dad and have many wonderful memories of sharing one with him while cheering on the Mets at Shea Stadium. 

Thanks Rena, this was a real TREAT!
As hard as any Friday for me, due to (I‚Äôm assuming) fairly basic trivia I just didn‚Äôt know. Eventually hit reveal rather than brute force three or four naticks.

Funny how people zero in on a minor stumble or two and blame the constructor.  I doubt that a natick or two made anyone's average time SOAR and if there had been nothing to WORKFOR there would have been a chorus of NE! NE! too easy!

I had fun working your puzzle, Rena.  Just ignore the Snyder comments.

Nice puzzle. Many thanks. 

I suspect that puzzle was selected so that Sam Corbin could make the knotty knotty joke. A good choice. üòÄ

Brezn are daily fare here.  Oddly in Bavaria die Brezn is feminine while das Brot is neuter. I‚Äôm trying to think of other examples but none come to mind. 

One bone to pick. ADDition is Arithmetic not Mathematics. It is awful that being an anarithmat seems to be socially acceptable. Being illiterate isn‚Äôt.

As someone who lives, not only on Spain, but the actual town where ZARA is headquartered, I was quite chuffed to see it in today's puzzle.  Interestingly, ZARA is owned by one of the world's richest people and Europes biggest philanthropists - Amancio Ortega.

Rena, if you frequent these comments, congrats on your fifth NYT puzzle as a college sophomore!! (I'm kind of IN AWE!) It was great fun and included some cute and clever clues and answers.

Wash U is a wonderful school, pretzels are a worthy theme, and I hope you have a great second year of college! 

OK, BYE!

The RAMADA x AARP crossing was just mean.

Also, pretzels aren't really a thing in Finland, which is something I just noticed and will now bother me.

Wooo! Today‚Äôs puzzle marks my 2000th gold star in a row and my 3620th puzzle in total! I‚Äôll have some pretzels to celebrate. (Really my streak should be a little longer, starting 1 Sept 2019, but I didn‚Äôt understand how streaks worked when I started; also I think the qualifying rules have changed a little since then.)
Nice little puzzle, but for the umpteenth time that useful word ‚Äòeke‚Äô is misdefined (see Webster).
Though not a fan of pretzels, I am a fan of this puzzle. Thanks for the fun, Rena. Now for a little Pretzel Logic. https://youtu.be/jT5eIvd7dZA?si=OkoVEySO0EDRV2L8

Cute Tuesday. Having never eaten a PRETZEL I had no idea they came in various shapes, but it didn‚Äôt stop me catching the theme.

I chuckled at  55D, as my ‚Äòrover‚Äô was chasing an empty cream pot aka his TREAT around the kitchen. 

I had a grumble re ZARA below; ridiculous sizes, both too small and yet too long for the average woman. I put it in the Abercrombie and Fitch category; intended for very thin, very young waifs.
A pretzel, perhaps from the Latin pretium (?), makes for a crunchy little reward. Good luck in your continuing studies, Rena. ‚ÄúWarsh U‚Äù is lucky to have you.
Oh come on. There are so many correct ways to clue ONE, but a countdown ends at *zero*!

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Three palindromes in the box (LIL, EKE, TET), plus a semordnilap pair (ONE/ENO), not to mention a pair of opposites (DROP/ASCEND).
‚Ä¢	I guessed at ZARA / SAL (inferred correctly), but would have preferred ZOLA / SOL.
‚Ä¢	Never heard of MOMAGER, but its wordplay brought out a big ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù
‚Ä¢	A backward IRON crossing TITANIUM made me wonder which is stronger, and a bit of research revealed it‚Äôs the latter, no contest.
‚Ä¢	The first three theme answers ‚Äì TITAINIUM ROD, TEETHING RING, and RUSSIAN TWIST ‚Äì not only have terrific pop, but are also NYT answer debuts.  Brava, Rena!
‚Ä¢	‚ÄúBravarena‚Äù sounds like a party dance.
‚Ä¢	SOARED plopped at the bottom next to LEAD made me think of ‚Äúlead balloon‚Äù.  Another "Hah!"

So, many happy pings for me in your savory concoction, Rena.  Thank you so much for making this!

Tough Tuesday for me, but that just made for a longer than usual workout. No big deal. Interesting that 3 of the referenced pretzel type answers were appearing for the first time in any puzzle. And even SELFIESTICK had only ever appeared twice before. And... there were 3 other debut answers in the downs. 

A couple of interesting puzzle finds today. I'll put those in a reply. 

..

A bit too much arcana for me in a Tuesday puzzle. Especially SAL/ZARA and INUK/ALTA. 

And fill like INEEDIT, IMTORN, ITRY, INAWE leaves me underwhelmed.

Solved, but not enjoyed.

Might just be grumpy since I failed at Wordle today. Won't say how, since that might spoil things for others.

Excellent! What I enjoyed here is that I felt like I was really working to drive through it (this was partially because -- due to the holiday -- I thought it was Monday and was alarmed at my pace) but ended up at a solid Tuesday time. Work + Progress = Satisfaction. Great job!

I had a lil trouble for a Tuesday but prevailed in the end. I was actually glad to Sal Khan make an appearance rather than "Lil Wayne featuring ____" or "Rapper Lil B tha ____" or whatnot. No slam against Lil Wayne or Lil B tha Grind... I've never heard their music, to be honest, but I suspect I'm a lil old for it.
For anyone who cares, today‚Äôs Spelling Bee has an S in it! And the world didn‚Äôt come to an end!

When it comes to pretzels vs. potato chips, I've always been a potato chip person (preferably with French onion dip), but today's puzzle reminded me of comedian David Brenner's memoir of growing up in Philadelphia, "Soft Pretzels with Mustard". https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQYNZtpzocg https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/910108.Soft_Pretzels_With_Mustard You used to be able to find them being hawked on the streets of Philly. Can anyone tell me if that's still a thing there?

Today was the opposite on my experience on Sunday. I got to SA_ crossed with E_ON as my last space to fill and thought I might have to try several letters, but I had seen those answers just enough times in the NYT xword  that L was my first guess and the little tune played. I started doing the crossword in late February  and now am getting all Mondays and the majority of Tuesdays without help. I have also gone back as far as February 2024, so that achievement is from a year and a half's worth of crosswords, not six months'. And I have long experience of cryptics in UK newspapers. My average solve times are coming down too, though it will take a long time to properly make up for initially needing over an hour for Wednesdays on wards and over two for Sundays.

SAL Khan and his eponymous Academy may not be well-known in these parts, but it's worth checking out. In general, I tend to be skeptical of "on-line learning", but I often used the videos from that site when teaching Art History in my History of Western Civilization course. Art History textbooks were becoming prohibitively expensive, and the lessons at Khan Academy were free. Steve Zucker and Beth Harris proved to be excellent teachers in helping students become more sophisticated viewers of the great works of Western Art. Here's a sample of their lessons: https://www.khanacademy.org/humanities/renaissance-reformation/high-ren-florence-rome/leonardo-da-vinci/v/celebrity-art-leonardo-s-mona-lisa https://www.khanacademy.org/humanities/ancient-art-civilizations/greek-art/classical/v/polykleitos-doryphoros-spear-bearer

I'm not familiar with Spanish fashion houses, and although I do know about Kahn academy, I didn't know the given name of its namesake. Two relatively obscure proper names intersecting...hmm. Imagine my frustrated fury and shame when I had to look something up in a Tuesday puzzle. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=8EnsUeR2MyI
After the past week or so, I finally committed NENE to memory. It's taken a long time but now I can fill it confidently.
I think it's great that the NYT x-word now recognizes  that the singular of INUIT is INUK, and we don't have to argue about that anymore.
Proper nouns proper nouns and more proper nouns. And a three-headed natick in the middle for laughs. Lousy puzzle

OOooooKAY.  PRETZEL STICKS:  check!  (Especially Dot's.)
Other than that, just SOFT PRETZELs or regular ole PRETZELs.  If someone offered me a PRETZEL ROD, or a RING, or a TWIST, I would look at them with narrowed eyes and decline ...just to be safe.  
Unfortunately, I did the extra puzzle (By Sam Donaldson) after that, and now I want to go around saying, "Foiled again!"

RUSSIAN TWIST...(mental image of Putin throwing his back out)... That's about it.  
OK BYE.
Another wonderful puzzle with a fun theme! Thanks so much, Rena! Hope all y‚Äôall have a terrific Tuesday!
Yum! I love puzzles made by young constructors because I finally actually know all the pop culture references and names! This was fun and quick for me (a rarity, honestly). Wonderful job.
What kind of solver are you, one who welcomes naticks kindly or one who  frowns upon them? I am the latter. üòü

I was STOKED to see the River OTTER finally getting some love; the sea-going variety has been dominant lately. I do love a hot (soft) PRETZEL at a football game, topped with plenty of stadium mustard. That's how we do it here.

OK BYE.
Superb puzzle today!
Crossing ZARA with SAL and INUK with ULTA did me in. Natick hell, those two.

Fortunately, I have visited ELON twice in the last year, and my son frequents our local ZARA, so those didn't have me, say, tied up in knots? üòÖ But I can see how those crosses were tricky. I myself had a....err.... problem area in the Monday puzzle that had me playing alphabet roulette (and probably were gimmes to others!). Loved the fresh clue for ANI, and always a pleasure to see our good friend the nesting NENE.

Very well done Rena. Having gone to Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster PA pretzels were an important part of our college experience! I've said it before and I'll probably say it again, any puzzle with NENE is a puzzle for me! I still remember how excited I got when first I saw one in HI!

Turns out there is a ZARA, which I had never heard of, at the big old Mall of America here in the Twin Cities but MOA is so not for me! Being a proper hostess, I only go there if I have visitors to the area who want to see it. 

Perhaps I would do better at some puzzles if I hung out at the MOA once in a while, but I actually do not think it would be worth it for me. Pretty sure there's an Auntie Annie's there though, and I do super love a big soft pretzel!! üòã  Still, I am not a mall girl and certainly not a mall on steroids girl! üòÜ 

Plus, happily, many of the tavern type establishments around here serve delicious big soft pretzels... Ooh, now I really want one!

However, there is an ULTA right here in Roseville and I also knew INUK, so it was only one tricky crossing for me by not knowing SAL, ELON, or ZARA. Oh well, sometimes the blind squirrel gets the nut, sometimes they don'. üêøÔ∏èüå∞

I did like seeing ELIE Wiesel and NESSIE both in there. And I liked thinking about the old Seinfeld bit of "These pretzels are making me thirsty!" 

All right, back to work with me!

Let Glen Campbell illustrate the difference between wanting and needing (salient line about 1:20): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q8P_xTBpAcY&list=RDQ8P_xTBpAcY&start_radio=1 (One of the most perfect songs ever penned, IMHO.)

I was very excited to see SAL Khan in the puzzle -- I felt very aligned with the constructor today as a young person lol, enjoyed the clues. I did very confidently fill in CHEXMIX instead of PRETZEL though... had to sadly delete once the crosses proved me wrong :(

My first fill-in for 56A was DANE, the whole while thinking, "Oh G.d, I hope not!" BUT-- It's worth considering-- Between about 2500BCE and 1CE, there was sporadic settlement of Greenland, by humans, from arctic North America. Between about 1CE and about 750CE, there were no humans, just polar bears. Dorset culture humans--who may or may not have been of Inuit stock--settled Greenland (from the west) about 750CE Norse culture humans settled Greenland (from the east) in 980CE. Thule culture humans--who were certainly Inuit--settled Greenland (again, from the west) about 1150CE. Obviously, there was contact between west and east. Not always happy. Now, I am in no way condoning colonialism. But we tend to think of aboriginal groups as existing, well, *ab origine*, when in fact, they came, at some time, from somewhere else as well. It is worth remembering that all human cultures migrate, expand, settle, colonize, displace: it's what we do. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norse_settlements_in_Greenland#/media/File:Grtemp.png
Never heard of a MOMAGER before.
Dory‚Äôs friend was Marlin, they were both seeking Nemo.

Sam:
One of the world's great fishing writers, John Gierach, published a collection of essays titled "Standing In A River Waving A Stick." Clearly, he was making a little joke about how others might perceive the fly fisher, but his advice in the book was spot on: "The solution to any problem-- work, love, money, whatever -- is to go fishing, and the worse the problem, the longer the trip should be." I'll be chasing steelhead in Oregon and B.C. this fall. The trips will be long ones...
2 naticks on a Tuesday. Came down to just a guessing game. Otherwise, nice.

Bit of a curate's egg. I enjoyed everything that wasn't Natick-y, but quite a lot was, even among clues I managed fine; as with many others though, Elon/Sal and Ulta/Inuk were icebergs. (Zara is familiar this side of the pond, and Inuk was eventually one of those ones that wriggled out of my memory when I saw it written down, but otherwise it was all new information.)

Based on my completion time, it was definitely more difficult than a usual Tuesday - for me. But I don‚Äôt have any complaints ü§ì. While I didn‚Äôt recall SAL Khan, ZARA and ELON were gimmes for me. Elon has been clued to the NC town/university so many times in the past few years, at this point I think it should be a gimme for most daily solvers.

The things I hadn‚Äôt heard of before were Russian twist and Inuk, but everything eventually filled in smoothly (if not particularly quickly) from the crosses and educated guesses.
I keep looking for the "extended guidelines" mentioned at the top of the comments. They are, in theory, at the bottom of the forum. Anyone else have any luck finding them?

Lots of fun to solve. Took me a tad longer than  Tuesdays usually do. 
My favorite theme answer was TITANIUM ROD, oddly enough. 
I had to have a titanium rod inserted into one leg from knee to ankle when I had a really bad bicycle accident in 2012. We were staying with friends in Tucson at the time and luckily for me, the local hospital deals with many similar cases. A very good surgeon operated on me the next day, which happened to be Thanksgiving Day. It was a couple of years before I could get back to hiking, and also quite a long time before I could fly back home to California. I‚Äôm still grateful to that surgeon.

I enjoyed this puzzle. Speaking of pretzels (the hard crunchy kinds), I'm not a fan; they are my least favorite snacking food. HOWEVER! I looooove milk-chocolate-covered pretzels; the combination of salt and chocolate are divine. (Also, Trader Joe's peanut butter filled pretzels covered with milk chocolate are also out of this world.)

As a diehard New Yorker (I lived there for a long time but moved to Paris two years ago to escape Cheeto Mussolini), I will always love those big soft pretzels sold from pushcarts on the street.

The clues in today's mini were so vague as to be unanswerable. I've done the mini every day for many years. I shoot for finishing in under a minute, and sometime I finish in under 30 seconds. But today's mini was so bad, I went on strike and abandoned it. C'mon, editors: how did you let that thing into print? Are you on strike, too?
Though I kinda wish one of the theme clues ended with ‚Äúsoft‚Äù, a pretzel themed puzzle fills my Philly heart. ü•®

What a delightful
Puzzle - thank you Rena! 

And speaking of delightful, HeathieJ, I so enjoy and appreciate your posts! Always positive, always kind, and frequently funny as well. Thank you!
The triple stacks of ISIS-NEMO-INUK and ZARA-ELON-SAL were pretty unfair, IMO.

Washington University has a beautiful campus. There was a wedding taking place there one time I drove by it. This puzzle was a beautiful Tuesday puzzle, a beautiful mix of the new and the familiar. Well done, Rena Cohen. Good luck with your studies and your mission.
Just wanted to say kudos for a simple, beautifully done Tuesday puzzle.

@Steven M.

SAL/ELON had me hunting down a typo for about a minute, which I'm not happy about.

@Steven M.

For me, SAL/ZARA was much worse.  But you're right, ELON makes it doubly tough.

@Steven M.

I first heard of Elon from the YouTube account Areyoukiddingtv.
@Steven M. If only there was some other Tuesday-appropriate way to clue ELON.

@SBK

This may be of interest.  From Wikipedia:

"By the year 2000, about 68 percent of Elon's students came from out-of-state and were only accepted if they met high academic standards.[5] Elon became known as a selective university and, by 2013, 82% of incoming students were from out of state.[6] Transforming a College: The Story of a Little Known College's Strategic Climb to National Distinction (2004), an academic study by George Keller of the University of Pennsylvania, chronicles how the school changed from a regional religious college to a selective, nationally recognized university."

"U.S. News & World Report ranks Elon tied for #133 overall among national universities and as #1 in the country for "Best Undergraduate Teaching." Elon is ranked as the #13 most innovative national university.[27] In 2020 Elon was the only university with top-10 rankings in all of U.S. News's "Academic Programs to Look For" categories."

@Al  in Pittsburgh
#133 among US universities overall? In the immortal words of Shania Twain, that don't impress me much. I too went to a small college but I don't expect it to be widely known. I'd still rate this use of ELON as Naticky.
@Steven M. I think I probably agree with you but have no idea what a ‚ÄúNatick‚Äù is. (Also ‚ÄúEmu‚Äù. Naticks and Emus are the Oreos and antes of the comments!)

@Petrol Seems to be my day for putting up links. Here is Wiktionary's definition of Natick: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/natick A glance will show you why these discussions occur. One person's obscure is another's obvious. So my Natick may have disrupted your solving not at all, while leaving me grinding my gears.

@SBK
133rd out of about 4,000 isn't too bad.

@SBK

Given the vast number of times it has appeared in the puzzle, ELON shouldn't be considered a Natick.

@Phil C.

Musk we?

@Times Rita
With this cluing, I'd still say Natick.
@JJ Came here to say just that.

@JJ

I had Z-RA and was able to guess that ZARA was a more likely name for a fashion chain, but I cycled every letter to get the SAL/ELON square.

@JJ

Me, too.  Especially SAL/ZARS for me.

Never heard of Sal Kahn of Kahn Academy, nor of the Spanish fashion retailer.

(I am ignorant of everything involving fashion--and I'm proud of it.)
@JJi got them wrong.  Rest of fill no issue.  I was thinking this is hard for a Tuesday.  Oh well‚Ä¶onward.

@Francis

You have heard of it though - my memory is worse than my manners, yet I recall encountering Khan academy at least three times in the past two years of doing these puzzles. If I remember three cases, there must have been a dozen in reality ü§£.

@Andrzej

Well, maybe.  I don't trust my memory much these days.  

When it came up before, was SOL part of the blue or answer?

Maybe one of our superb statisticians can tell us when it appeared most recently?

@Francis

Of course I misread your previous comment. Kahn Academy is what I remember seeing here, not the guy's first name, d'oh!

@Andrzej

You still had me.  I said, and I still say, that I don't recall anything about Kahn Academy.

@Andrzej

SAL has been clued to the Khan Academy six times, all since 2021.

@Steve L
Thanks. Trustworthy data is always helpful.

(I am ignorant of everything involving fashion--and I'm proud of it.)

Francis,
You don't have to wear it to be aware of it.

@Barry Ancona

Your playfulness with the language is hilarious.

@Barry Ancona

P. S. To my above reply.  I bet you wrote some legendary headlines.

@JJ Ulta sells beauty products and Zara sells trendy fashion. They might skew toward a gender/sexuality/generational cohort that you are not a part of, but a lot of clues and answers do that for me. I just take a guess or look things up, rather than blame someone else for my lack of knowledge. 

I think it‚Äôs impressive and amazing that a college sophomore has published so many crosswords in the NYT.

@Andrzej

The fill didn‚Äôt bother me, but I agree the theme was a little meh. Seems like if you are going to have a pretzel theme some grid art would be nice.

@SP

Also, as a European and connoisseur of bread, I have a personal issue with what pretzel means in American English. The original German Bretzel, and the Polish precel, are a very distinct, large-ish treat of soft bread, with a crunch-ish, salted crust. Biting into one feels heavenly - the shock of the salt, the slight resistance of the crust, the delicate, almost sweet dough inside - what an experience! The crispy, tiny American pretzels share nothing with their European ancestors, except the knotted shape.

@Andrzej

The city of Philadelphia is noted for its "soft pretzels".  Sounds similar to what you described.
I have no first-hand knowledge or experience.

I read that the recipes have Bavarian origins.
@Andrzej welcome back. Hope you had a great holiday.
Soft pretzels are also sold on the streets of New York and at the ball parks (and at other select and not so select retail and dining venues).

@Times Rita

There‚Äôs also another mall chain called Wetzel‚Äôs Pretzels similar to Auntie Anne‚Äôs.
@Andrzej  your comment about snacks intrigued me. If not salty, were snacks sweet? Or was there simply no snacking?
@SP yep, I fleetingly looked for some Pretzel Logic in the grid

@C

You have no idea how bad scarcity was under the soviet-aligned regime here. Shelves in the (state-owned) stores were half empty. Some articles were almost never in stock, like meat and toilet paper. There were two kinds of cheese (generic "yellow" cheese, and "white" cheese, akin to German Quark), one type of sugar, one type of flour, etc. If there were any salty snacks available ar all, it was paluszki.

@Andrzej
Thank you so much for your reply. I‚Äôm thankful for the positive changes. Would be more grateful if we knew we were continuing a strong path forward

@Banjo Nelson

Any major dude will tell you that sometimes a grid just doesn't lend itself to a special configuration.

@Andrzej

I do know. My first trip to Eastern Europe was in the summer of 1979. While that trip didn't include Poland, we did go to Romania, still under the reign of Nicolae Ceau»ôescu. Finding a hotel and restaurant in Bucharest was difficult enough. But when we got to Transylvania, the weather was rainy and cold. In those pre-internet days, it was hard to determine what to expect climate-wise. I needed socks, which I never thought I'd need in summer. I went to the local excuse for a department store, where I had to get on a line (queue), and when it came my turn at the register, I asked for socks. No choice at all, just what they had. And I felt lucky to be able to get those!

@Mike
Cheez-Its getting harder and harder to come up with a reply.
@Mike three words to describe your puns: naughty, dry, crackers!

@Sandy
These pretzels...are making me thirsty!
@Sandy Actually it's from "Woody Allen" (since he writes all his movies).
@Francis. LOL‚Ä¶I wrote the same comment! üòÇ

@Francis

üòÇ I thought of it too!! üòÇ

@Paul R

Yeah, that was quite a one-two punch.

I was mostly, but not completely sure about INUK.

ULTA was completely new.

@Francis

I was about to make a comment about not getting to the malls when I found that the nearest ULTA store was 4 hours from Grand Marais.

TIL that you are close to the border and areas captured by the Group of Seven.  Sounds like heaven.

Though probably getting chilly this time of year.:)

@Al  in Pittsburgh

I really have no excuse, because those 4 hours are to the Twin Cities, where I've lived for 22 years, and about half time now.

I do love it in Grand Marais both the scenery and the weather.  I feel privileged to be able to live in such a place. 

Actually, falls are generally a little warmer than one might think, because Lake Superior has warmed over the summer (although it's still cold) but that relative warmth lasts fairly deep into fall).

Conversely, the spring temperatures seem to be a little cooler than it might be without the Lake.

One final comment:  I once saw on a weather site two temperatures for Grand Marais:  one was the airport (yes, Grand Marais has an teensy airport, as well as a sea plane base) which is about seven miles inland.  

They also had a temperature for the harbor in Grand Marais.

The airport was 83F and the harbor was 47F.

You can literally sometimes feel the temperature change walking a block or two one direction or another.

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: I've never encountered anything like this before. Two puzzles with the same theme and a couple of duplicate answers, and... three fifteen letter theme answers in both of them and in exactly the same location in both puzzles. First a Monday from April 28, 1975 by Woss (?). All of the theme clues in that one were "A first lady." And those three theme answers from top to bottom: MARYTODDLINCOLN MAMIEEISENHOWER LADYBIRDJOHNSON And then... a Monday from October 21, 1991 by Melvin Kenworthy. The clue for each of those theme answers was of the form "Wife of the 27th U.S. President." And then 16th and 3rd presidents. And those answers in order: HELENHERRONTAFT MARYTODDLINCOLN MARTHAJEFFERSON So... we've had five first ladies with 15 letter names and...NONE of them have ever been answer in a Shortz era puzzle. Furrowed brow. Here are the links to those two puzzles: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/28/1975&g=20&d=A https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=10/21/1991&g=37&d=A I'm done. ...

@Rich in Atlanta Oh.. and one more. One of the oddest puzzles I've ever encountered. A Sunday from April 13, 2003 by Charles Deber with the title "What am I?" Here are the theme clues and answers in order: "If I have ___ :" SEVENTYTWODARKSQUARES "... and I am ___ :" TWENTYONEBYTWENTYONE "... and I am ___ :" MODERATELYCHALLENGING "... and I have ___ :" ONEHUNDREDFORTYWORDS "... then I must be ___ :" TODAYSCROSSWORDPUZZLE Whew. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/13/2003&g=23&d=A ..

Leo,

Naticks?  What naticks?

I have recently arrived here on Earth from my home planet Xfrthpr, so bear with me if my interpretation proves to be incorrect.

Based upon studying comments about this puzzle as well as some in the past, I conclude that "Natick" means "I didn't know the answer, but it's not my fault because it was unfair of the constructor and/or editor to expect me to know such a thing."  

As I acquire more data, I will update my asssessment if necessary.

@Nancy J.

I might consider something a natick without considering it unfair or the constructor's fault that I did not know either cross.

@Jim

Thank you.  I will add that to my data bank.

@Nancy J. 
As I understand it, a natnick is when two proper nouns cross and so neither cannot be solved definitively without knowing the trivia. Usually it‚Äôs considered better form on the part of the constructor to have other types of answers crossing proper nouns so that the puzzle can be solved even if one doesn‚Äôt know a name.
@Nancy J. For me, naticks are all the constructor's fault.

@Jim 
Wrong. A natick occurs wherever two or more proper nouns are required to solve a particular clue or clues.
@Leo It‚Äôs the constructor‚Äôs fault that you don‚Äôt know something?

LJADZ,

Wrong! The original natick was when Rex didn't know the first letter of the city near Boston, and couldn't infer the first initial of N. C. Wyeth (which he couldn't remember). 

Rex subsequently broadened the meaning to be the crossing of two words -- not necessarily proper nouns -- where "most solvers" would not be expected to know either word (and thus would be stuck on the crossing letter). 

Natick never meant just the cross of two proper nouns.
I see the Natick Police finally stopped biting their tongues, ü§£

I just reread all of the Wordplay comments for a  puzzle six years ago -- 9/7/2019 -- that both Jeff and Jim at xwordinfo.com called quite tough. Commenters agreed it was a toughie, and it had a fair number of proper nouns. The word "natick" does not appear in any of the comments.
